newsitem.title: USA: Kansas lawmakers push move to scrap property tax.
newsitem.headline: Kansas lawmakers push move to scrap property tax.

text.p: A plan to eliminate Kansas' tax on residential property and reduce it on commercial property could come up for a vote by the state's House of Representatives as early as next Tuesday.

The House of Representatives' Taxation Committee voted Wednesday to send the plan to the floor for a vote. In doing so, the committee shunned Kansas Gov. Bill Graves' proposed 17-percent across-the board tax cut.
The bill approved by the committee would eliminate school property taxes on single-family homes this year and trim taxes on all other types of property by about 25 percent.
House Democrats have lined up with the Republican governor to oppose the sweeping property tax cut, which would lower property tax bills by an estimated $166 million.
Graves' plan would cut property taxes by $40.5 million this year and $89.3 million in 1998, according to a spokesman for Graves.
The spokesman said Graves' proposed property tax cuts were part of his overall effort to cut $112 million in taxes during the budget year that Begins July 1.
